messages.content: You are tasked with creating a structured output from the provided user message.

Full HTTP request path
- /api/v1/users/{user}

Reasoning
- The UserController@show endpoint is registered in routes/api.php under:
  - Route::apiResource('users', UserController::class)->only(['index', 'show']); (outside the auth group)
  - This maps GET /api/v1/users/{user} to show.
- The same path also has a separate registration for update via:
  - Route::apiResource('users', UserController::class)->only('update'); (inside the auth group)
  - This maps PUT/PATCH /api/v1/users/{user} to update.
- The v1 prefix is applied to API routes, so the final path includes /api/v1.

Acceptance of HTTP methods (based on code)
- All HTTP methods acceptable: No
  - The endpoint only defines specific methods via route registrations (GET for show; PUT/PATCH for update on the same path, and no POST/DELETE/OPTIONS defined for this resource on this path).
- HEAD: Yes
  - HEAD is implicitly supported for GET routes in Laravel. Since show uses GET, HEAD is acceptable for this endpoint.
- GET: Yes
  - Show is implemented via GET /api/v1/users/{user}.
- POST: No
  - There is no POST route defined for /api/v1/users/{user} (POST would be for creating a user, not the show endpoint).
- PUT: Yes
  - The update method is registered for the same path via the authenticated group: PUT /api/v1/users/{user}.
- PATCH: Yes
  - The update method is registered for the same path via the authenticated group: PATCH /api/v1/users/{user}.
- DELETE: No
  - There is no DELETE route for /api/v1/users/{user} in the provided routes.
- OPTIONS: No
  - There is no explicit OPTIONS route defined for this endpoint. Laravel does not define an OPTIONS route for this path based on the code given.

Explanation
- The endpoint for showing a user is defined in the public (non-auth) API routes as GET /api/v1/users/{user} (index/show). 
- The same resource path also has a protected update route (PUT/PATCH) defined in a separate group, which is why PUT/PATCH are considered acceptable on this same path as well.
- HEAD is considered acceptable because Laravel automatically handles HEAD for existing GET routes.
- POST, DELETE, and OPTIONS are not defined for this path in the provided code, so they are not acceptable for this endpoint.
